May 20, 1992
Smoking, Genetics, and Lung Cancer
Cincinnati-Seven percent of all smokers die of iung cancer. Bur why only seven percent. and which seven our
of a hundred are at risk? Scientists at the University of Cincinnati (UC) Medical Center may have found a clue
in DNA.
A rescarch team led by Daniel W. Nebers, ME, UC Environmental Health, have discovered thar two
human genes, on chromosome 15, are linked to enzymes that react with procarcinogens found in the blood of
all smokers. This lethal chemical reaction berween the enzymes and the procarcinogens creates toxic carcinogens
that canse cancer. Humans normally have 23 pairs of chromosomes or long chains of genes. "A particular
difference in either gene can lead to greater intensity of action or toxiciry in one individual but not another,"
says Nebert.
Smokers with these two genes are more likely to develop cancer, but can protect chemselves by quitting
smoking. Fusure blood tests could tell us who has a predisposition for a specific type of cancer. But a person
with bad genes isn't neceasarily doomed. In other words, the person can avoid the procarcinogens by choosing
not to smoke. The body chemistry of each person is somewhat unique. "Each of us is different with regard to
drug-metabolizing capabilities," says Nebert
Diet, the immune system, aging, and environment, all play important roles in the cancer process and diet
